In Julia, Write a function `clean_column` that cleans a column name (`col`) by lowercasing it, stripping any leading or trailing whitespaces, and replacing any spaces and hyphens with an underscore, eg, "My Column" becomes "my_column".

In Julia, you can define a function `clean_column` to clean column names as follows:

```julia
function clean_column(col::String)
    return lowercase(replace(col, r"^\s+|\s+$" => "")) # Strip leading and trailing whitespace
        |> replace(' ' => '_')                          # Replace spaces with underscores
        |> replace('-' => '_')                          # Replace hyphens with underscores
end
```

This function takes a `String` as input, removes any leading or trailing whitespaces using the regular expression `r"^\s+|\s+$"`, and then replaces both spaces and hyphens with underscores. The pipe (`|>`) operator is used to chain the functions together.

You can test this function by calling it on some column names:

```julia
julia> clean_column("My Column")
"my_column"

julia> clean_column("my column")
"my_column"

julia> clean_column("My-Column")
"my_column"

julia> clean_column("1st Col")
"1st_col"
```

This function is designed to work with strings that already contain only ASCII characters, as it does not perform any encoding conversions. If you need to work with non-ASCII characters or if the input string might contain invalid Unicode code points, you may want to add additional checks and handling in your function.
